awd_titl_txt: Shape, wobble, and roll: adaptation of bacterial morphology to mechanical environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria have consistent sizes and shapes that are linked to the nature of their living environments. Cocci (with spherical shapes) and bacilli (with rod-like shapes) are generally found as clusters in soil and mammalian gastrointestinal tract, while spiral-shaped bacteria are known for their ability to move efficiently through dense media. The aim of this work is to elucidate how shape and size determine the adaptation of a bacterial strain to an environment with specified rheological properties. This work is facilitated by an automated tracking microscope that resolves the shape and motion of free-living microorganisms in 3D. The project will pursue a purely mechanical approach in examining the extent to which bacterial morphology is an indicator of cell fitness and virulence. This study also aims to be a guide to the design of robotic micro-scale swimmers that need to move efficiently through complex fluid media in order to deliver drugs or kill pathogenic cells in a timely manner. The innovation of the automated microscope will contribute to an interactive educational program at a local high school where high school students will be taught how to use a 3D printer to design and optimize experimental implements. 

This project will develop a framework that maps the selective bacterial morphology to the specific rheological properties of the living habitats. The proposed study focuses on answering the following questions: how the cell body of a microorganism contributes to its swimming motility; how different cell shapes produce marked rheological effects; and whether these environmental effects can be utilized to manipulate cell shapes. The morphology of an individual cell and its three-dimensional movements will be measured under an automated tracking microscope. The PI will design and create gradients of rheological features for each individual bacterium using microfluidic devices fabricated through photolithography. Combined with the tracking microscopy, the PI will study the direct impact of non-Newtonian features of the surrounding media on the motion of individual cells. The PI will also create microfluidic devices to introduce temporal-dependent "selective" pressures, and aim to isolate phenotypes preferred by the fluid environment. Such devices can be used to directly control the phenotypic expressions of live biological systems and will shed light on how phenotype variations allow the same species to adapt to various living habitats. Ultimately, this work aims at creating new approaches for controlling the activities and functions of microorganisms through the hydrodynamic properties of its fluid environment. It will also guide future design of micro-scale robots for medical and industrial applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Microorganism-media interactions occur in almost every aspect of ecology, the environment, and our health. This project aims to address the mutual impacts of individual shapes and the mechanical features of environments on the transport of microorganisms.

Significant achievements are highlighted below.

1. Geometry-enhanced transport in structured environments. Motile bacteria mediate with structured habitats through complex mechanical interactions, including hydrodynamic, steric, and electrostatic forces. The PI found that the long-term transport of bacteria switches from trapping dominated state for shorter cells to a much more dispersive state for longer cells above a critical bacterial size set by the pillar array geometry. Using a combination of a multiscale experiment and geometry-based modeling, the PI showed that this anomalous size dependence arises from an enhancement of the escape rate from trapping for longer cells restricted geometrically by nearby pillars. These results show that geometric effects can lead to size being a sensitive tuning knob for transport in structured environments, with implications in general for active matter systems and, in particular, for the morphological adaptation of bacteria to structured habitats, spatial structuring of communities, and anti-biofouling materials design (Chopra et al. 2022).
2. Surface-affiliated bacterial motility of sessile-motile aggregates. Microbial dispersal in an aqueous environment can be active or passive, based on the mechanism driving dispersion. A sessile-motile aggregate leads to an intermediate dispersal regime where active and passive dispersals coexist within one dispersal unit. Through a multiscale study (Motility of sessile-motile bacterial aggregates"), The PI showed that the rosettes, although predominantly sessile, can actively disperse through the flagellar motors of motile members. The PI further revealed that their proximity to a solid-liquid interface promotes wheel-like rolling, as powered by the flagellar torque. This rolling movement also features a sequence of sharp turns, a reorientation mechanism distinct from swimming cells. Overall, this study elucidates an unexplored regime of aggregation-based motility that can be widely applied to sessile-motile composites (Zeng and Liu, 2020).

3. Hydrodynamic effects of the cell body in swimming bacteria. Through a hydrodynamic model that incorporates precessing cell bodies with various geometries, the PI identified a critical cell size threshold at which a transition from quiescent to precession movement occurs, associated with a Hopf bifurcation. Furthermore, the PI showed that the observed precession movement synergizes with the size and shape of the cell body for optimized swimming motility. The PI also elucidated that the finite sizes of the cell bodies of free-living bacteria represent a compromise between speed and energy saving. This finding thus implies potential evolutionary pressure from hydrodynamics on cellular morphology and will alter our current understanding of the functions of cell shapes (Liu and Gonzalez, 2020).

This project also provided training for undergraduate and graduate students, a postdoctoral researcher, and visiting scholars, including high school students. In addition to experimental skills, these pieces of training also include scientific communications and leadership in scientific and outreach activities. 

The GUI-based tracking tool, the 3D reconstruction approach, and the hydrodynamic modeling of a rosette near a solid surface (developed in this project) were deposited to an open-access code repository (Zenodo.org) for public use. In addition, the numeric code of the geometry-based kinematics of bacteria in structured media was deposited in Github for public use. 

A virtual lab environment and a compact microfluid kit developed in this project were employed by the PI in curricular teaching and workshops for the public, including the K12 scholars.
